In double conditional sentences, the conditional sub-clause precedes the main
clause with the conclusion. In most cases, there is no conjunction in the sub-
clause. The verb in the main clause is in the irrealis mood (cf. Section 5.8 in
Chapter 5), if the sentence refers to the past, otherwise it takes the general
inflections for aorist or future. A converb form is used in the sub-clause. The
temporal reference of the two clauses need not be the same.
   In the sentences below the sub-clause is in the past, while the main clause is
in the present. The main verb of the main clause is in the irrealis form, while the
main verb of the sub-clause is in the past, accompanied by the converb of the
copula. In sentences (43a) and (43b) both clauses refer to the past. In sentence
(43a) the clauses express simultaneity. In the main clause, the verb is inflected
for irrealis, while in the sub-clause the verb takes the past tense marker and it
is accompanied by the conditional form of the BE-verb. In sentence (43b) the
time reference is not the same, because there is an anterior relation. The verb
in the main clause is also inflected for irrealis. As the irrealis cannot be used in
the past, only the subordinate clause marks the temporal reference of the main
clause: the past participle of the verb is followed by the past tense form of the
existential verb and the converb of the existential verb. Although both clauses
refer to the past, the circumstances caused the consequence, i.e. this is a case
of antecedence.

6.3.2.4      Inchoative and Resultative Suffixes
Nganasan also has perfectivizing suffixes, which express a normally inchoative,
resultative or temporal meaning. One of the most frequently used derivational
suffixes is the inchoative suffix -LƏ (-lə, -lʲi) with the meaning ‘begin to S’, e.g.
hiďisʲi ‘laugh’ > hisʲi-lə-sʲi ‘begin to laugh’; ďaŋhɨďi ‘shine’ > ďaŋhɨ-lə-sɨ ‘begin
to shine’; ďorəďa ‘cry’ > ďorə-lə-sa ‘begin to cry’. This suffix can also express
semelfactivity, i.e. to indicate that the action happened only once. The stem of
such verbs is always a durative verb referring to a lengthy action, e.g. ďorəďa
‘cry’ > ďorə-lə-sa ‘cry out’; səŋü-r-sa ‘look’ cf. səŋü-lə-sa ‘catch sight of’; hiďisʲi
‘laugh’ > hisʲi-lə-sʲi ‘burst out laughing’. In contrast to Nenets (cf. Nikolaeva 2014:
46), the derivative in Nganasan does not belong to the reflexive inflectional
class, the verb can be conjugated by subjective or objective conjugation as well.
   The inchoative-resultative suffix-Ɂkə is a very frequent and productive deri-
vational suffix. It appears on the S1 stem of the verb. The derivative is always a
perfective verb (S1: V+-Ɂkə → VPerf). The meaning of the derived word is ‘begin
to do something and probably finish doing it as well’; ďarəðɨ-sɨ ‘be ill’: ďarəðɨ-
word formation                                                                      533Ɂkə-ďi ‘fall ill’; kitə-ďi ‘wake somebody up’: kitə-Ɂkə-sa ‘begin waking somebody
up’; ŋəm-sa ‘eat’: ŋəmə-Ɂkə-sa ‘begin to eat’(42) a. tahari͡aa təndɨ-čə            tolɨ-Ɂkə-sɨðə-Ɂ ńeraɁa.

The frequentative suffix -r is primarily used as an aspect marker: it forms imper-
fective verbs, but it also carries its original, frequentative meaning, e.g. ŋəmsa
‘eat (up)’ > ŋəmursa ‘eat’; mənəgəisʲa ‘fall down’ > mənəgəirsʲa ‘fall down usu-
ally’; laŋəɁkəsa ‘shout’ cf. laŋürsʲa ‘shout occasionally’; tolɨďi ‘steal something’
> tolarsa ‘steal occasionally’
    Words with the suffix -ɁnA2r (-(Ɂ)nar, -(Ɂ)ni͡ar) describe events that are
repeated within irregular intervals in a certain period of time. The derivational
suffix is morphologically complex. It is made up of two suffixes with a fre-
quentative meaning, although the -na morpheme is not used as a separate
derivational suffix in present day Nganasan. The meaning of words with the
-r frequentative suffix (see above) describe events repeated more regularly, as
the sentences in the corpus show. Examples: büü-ďa ‘go away’ > büü-Ɂnar-sa ‘go
away more than once’; kou-ďa ‘drop behind’ > kou-Ɂnar-sa ‘drop behind more
than once’; tuj-sʲa ‘arrive’ > tuu-Ɂnar-sa ‘come’.(44) a. ŋuɁəð -ə      kobtu͡a-nə       ďa bənsə-ruɁ tuu-Ɂnar-u-ruɁ.

Adverbs can be formed from adjectives or nouns with several derivational suf-
fixes or certain case suffixes, for example with the genitive plural suffixes -Ɂ
(ńaagəǝ: ńaagəiɁ ‘good’ [adv]) and with the prolative suffixes -mənu (ərəkərə:
ərəkərə-mənu ‘beautifully’). Both suffixes form adverbs of manner. (For the case
suffixes, see Section 3, Chapter 4).

nouns, e.g. ŋənduj ‘boat’: ŋəndujkalʲi ‘without a boat’; tuj ‘fire’: tuj-kalʲi ‘without

with the word ičuə, which is the present participle form of the copula (isʲa), e.g.

           ChNS_080214_Hibula_flkd.0307       Clitic-like MorphemesThere are some morphemes in Nganasan whose morphological status is not
determined with certainty. Based on the way they are used, they form an inter-
mediate category between derivational suffixes and clitics. They are character-
ized by not behaving consistently: their position can depend on the speaker or
the part of speech of the word as well. Practically all of them can co-occur with
verbal and nominal stems, but not with the same frequency: some morphemes
occur more frequently with nominal stems. But their position in relation to
each other is set, although they do not occur together very often. The following
morphemes belong to this group: -Küə, -KüCmü, -ŋUTU, -ŋA2lə, -Kəlʲičə, -btA2,
-Cčǝ and -uɁ. In the discussion below, I will refer to these morphemes as “clitic-
like morphemes”.

1        Coding of Recipient and AddresseeAs mentioned above, the recipient is the receiver of an object which is trans-
ported to him by an agent argument. The most typical recipient is animate.
There is more than one possibility to mark a recipient. The marking of the recip-
ient depends on the type of verb. The argument of physical transfer verbs takes
the lative suffix, while the argument of mental transfer verbs takes a postposi-
tional phrase.

           ChND, 20161.2      Postpositional Coding
There are two postpositions used in the construction: the allative postposition
ďa and the postposition na ‘to, near’. Their usage depends on the type of verb.
If the verb denotes mental transfer, i.e. it is a verb of speech (‘tell’, ‘say’ etc.)
or a verb of explication (‘show’ etc.), the recipient-like participant (addressee)
cannot be encoded with the lative/dative case, it must be expressed by a post-
positional phrase with the allative postposition ďa. If the participant is a true
recipient, the verb expresses physical transfer and the postposition ďa cannot
be used. In this case, the inflected postposition na ‘to, near’ is used, marked for
case with an ancient case marker (cf. Section 4.1.2 in Chapter 3), and takes a
possessive suffix from the oblique series.

6.1.1        Evaluative Suffixes
The inventory of evaluative suffixes, which consists of diminutives and aug-
mentatives, is quite rich. The augmentatives signal a bigger version of the
basis. There are four augmentative suffixes: -Ɂəə, -Ɂa, -Ɂuə and -RbA1ɁƏ (-rbaɁa,
-rbɨɁə). The -Ɂuə (-Ɂüə) derivational suffix occurs only with persons’ names,

1.1         S1-Stem
This stem is considered as the basic stem and it is determined by removing the
infinitive suffix from the infinitive form of the verb: tujsʲa ‘come’: tuj-; konɨďi ‘go
away’: konɨ-; bɨðɨrsʲa ‘drink’: bɨðɨr-.
    There are however cases, where, under the effect of the phonological rules,
removing the infinitive ending does not yield the S1-stem, but a form that
cannot be suffixed. This is mostly true of the verbs which S1-stem ends in -j.
This stem-ending -j in many cases has merged with the infinitive ending and
palatalized its consonant, and synchronically is no longer visible (for palatal-
ization and deletion see Section 7.3 and Section 7.6 in Chapter 2). The verb
‘be’ and existential verbs containing the verb ‘be’ belong to this group, as i-sʲa
‘be’: ij-; təi-sʲa ‘exist’: təij-; təni-sʲa ‘exist’: tənij-. The /j/ has disappeared from all
forms of these verbs, but the forms themselves show that it is present in the

‘be’, which has on the surface the non-motivated palatalization, and is seem-

is’.

speakers. For additional information about these forms, see chart (6) in Section

1.2       S2-Stem
There is more than one way of forming this stem. Either by removing the imper-
ative 2sg suffix -Ɂ from the imperative form of the verb, or by removing the
ending -Ɂ from the connegative form of the verb: tuɁ ‘come [imp.2sg or cng]’:
tu-; konɨɁ ‘go [imp.2sg or cng]’: konɨ-; bɨtɨrəɁ ‘drink [imp.2sg or cng]’: bɨtɨrə-.
The S1 and the S2 forms of vowel-final stems are generally identical.
    The stems with the stem ending consonants -m, -n, -r and -l generally do not
alternate, the S2 stem is identical to the S1 stem, as in bəjkum-sa ‘get older’: S1=S2
bəjkum-; hon-sa ‘spin’: S1=S2 hon-; hojküür-sa ‘run’: S1=S2 hojküür-; buəgəlsa
‘talk’: S1=S2 buəgəl-.

the final consonants. These verbs are listed below in chart (5). These are mainly
polysyllabic imperfective verbs.

with a short vowel, and in the S3 stem, a vowel alternation appears. There are
also verbs, whose stems do not alternate in their S2 stem, but the vowel alterna-
tion can be witnessed in S3. (For both verb types see chart (8) below.) There is
another group of shortening stems—mostly disyllabic stems—which shorten
in their S2 variant, but exhibit no alternation in S3. These verbs are listed in
chart (4).
